awd_abstract_narration:
In Alaska, LSAMP has catalyzed the development of a comprehensive longitudinal model that begins with middle school students, extends on through high school, into the undergraduate years, on to graduate school and into the professions. This model improves the quality of education while decreasing the cost. LSAMP is the university undergraduate portion of the multi-stage model that started twenty one years ago. The objective is to effect a systemic change in the hiring patterns of Alaska Natives in the STEM professions. There are approximately 2,000 students in the pipeline. It is established that this multi-stage model improves the preparation, increases the participation, and ensures the contributions of minority students in the STEM enterprise.   

The project goals are to: 1. build upon the work in progress at the transitions between high school and college, and from undergraduate to graduate school; 2. provide new LSAMP staff personnel on Alliance campuses; 3. expand the capacity for undergraduate research and build the capacity to conduct international research; 4. strengthen LSAMP presence on the Alliance Community campuses. 5. Conduct internal and external research studies assessing the longitudinal model effectiveness.

Internal and external research studies are helping to refine the model and assist LSAMP and the wider community of stakeholders in learning about effective practices to broaden participation in the scientific workforce.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The LS-AMP Alaska Alliance is the BS-STEM undergraduate portion of a comprehensive longitudinal model that starts with middle school students and extends into the PhD. The project objective is to effect a systemic change in the hiring patterns in the fields of STEM by increasing the number of underrepresented minority individuals on a career path that can have a seat at the table making decisions for the benefit of the state of Alaska. During this grant period, there were 123 STEM graduates. In addition, there were 152 summer bridge students on the pathway to becoming STEM professionals through internships with our partners and the number of student participants are increasing.. Currently, we have over 100 partners that provide funding and internships for our students., The goals of this grant were to:

1. Additional improvements to the undergraduate education experience by building upon done at the critical junctures of the transition between high school and college and the transition from undergraduate to graduate school.

2. expansion of capacity for undergraduate research.

3. building capacity to conduct international research projects.

4. strengthening LSAMP presence on the Alliance Community campuses.

As a result of the LS-AMP Alaska Alliance funding we have increased the number of underrepresented minority students matriculating into STEM degrees. Along with, this grant has helped start an international research initiative that has placed students in New Zealand, China and Greenland. In addition, we have grown the number of underrepsented minority faculty in STEM from zero to three at the University of Alaska and two more that are candidates for being tenure-track faculty after their graduation in the coming years. These are the first tenure-track faculty that are Alaska Native in their STEM disciplie at the University of Alaska Anchorage,


Last Modified: 10/30/2023
Modified by: Matthew E Calhoun
